#Text=Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen
#Text=Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen ( before 1470 – 1533 ) was a Northern Netherlandish designer of woodcuts and painter .
#Text=He was one of the first important artists working in Amsterdam , at a time when it was a flourishing provincial town .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Painting a Portrait of His Wife
#Text=Little is known about Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen 's life .

#Text=Historians rely mostly on the biographical sketch of him written by Karel van Mander , the archives of Amsterdam , and the archives of Egmond Abbey , a Benedictine monastery that commissioned works by him . His name indicates he was from Oostzaan , North Holland , east of the river Zaan , north of Amsterdam .
#Text=His family managed land in that area .
#Text=A good impression of life there in those times can be had by a visit to the Zaanse Schans .
#Text=His entire family were painters .
#Text=Cornelis Buys I , also known as Master of Alkmaar , was his brother , as was Cornelis Buys II .
#Text=His sons Cornelis Jacobz and Dirk Jacobsz became portrait painters , as did his grandsons Cornelis Anthonisz and Jacob Dirksz .
#Text=As birth or baptism dates have been lost , all of their birth dates have been approximated from other archival evidence such as death dates of other family members .
#Text=Similar to the archival evidence surrounding Frans Hals , the first known commissions for Jacob Cornelisz were from when he was at least 35 years of age .
#Text=It is assumed that he worked in a painters 's workshop before that , and judging from his close copies of Haarlem painting techniques , this was possibly in Haarlem .
#Text=He bought his first house in Amsterdam in 1500 , in the Kalverstraat .
#Text=Twenty years later he bought the neighboring house .
#Text=For this reason he is sometimes called Jacob Cornelisz van Amsterdam .
#Text=His wife is called a widow in archives for the first time in 1533 .
#Text=The last payments made to him according to the Egmond Abbey archives were in 1526 – 1528 for a retable ( lost during the troubles of the Protestant Reformation ) .
#Text=Career
#Text=Christ Appearing to Mary Magdalen as a Gardener
#Text=In his earlier years Jacob Cornelisz was under the influence of Haarlem painter Geertgen tot Sint Jans .
#Text=The colors and techniques suggest that he learned his craft in Haarlem .
#Text=His later influence then became painter Albrecht Dürer .
#Text=He may have gone to visit him in Antwerp in the 1520s .
#Text=The painting patterns of his earlier works suggest he was trained as a woodcut designer or goldsmith .
#Text=One of his first works was Christ as a gardener. . [ 1 ]
#Text=There are about 200 known woodcuts and 27 paintings by Cornelisz .
#Text=His prints are traditional north Netherlandish small-scale book illustrations .
#Text=Writings are used to present the narrative with actions placed in the foreground .
#Text=Throughout his artistic career Cornelisz 's painting style changed .
#Text=At first he started as a late Gothic craftsman under the influence of the Haarlem school and then ended with a style presented by the painting Saul and the Witch of Endor .
#Text=In this particular painting the details are simple , elongated proportions and a looser stroke of paint .
#Text=Though he excelled as a technical painter , he was not a good leader .
#Text=He progressed at presenting contemporary trends in subject-matter and style .
#Text=Cornelisz 's symbolism was also conservative as well .
#Text=He painted mostly sacred themes with traditional iconography in old and new combinations in response to an event , such as the Reformation .

#Text=Some of his works such as Christ as the Man of Sorrows ( 1510 ) were used by biblical humanists and the Amsterdam oligraphy , who wanted to defend Catholic orthodoxy against the claims of early Reformers .
#Text=The painting represented Roman Catholic beliefs in an easily understood format .
#Text=Other paintings such as The Nativity ( 1512 ) and Saul and the Witch of Endor were visually similar to what the Catholic essays patrons were writing .
#Text=Later in his life Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen ran a workshop with pupils , like his son Dirk Jacobsz and Jan van Scorel did after him .
#Text=In the workshop , his assistants helped him design book illustrations , woodcuts and stained-glass windows .
#Text=After 1526
#Text=Jacob produced only one known painting , Self Portrait ( 1533 ) .
#Text=Scholars were led to believe this was the year of his death , but according to Dutch historian I. H van Eeghen there was a seven-year gap between paintings , which was unusual .
#Text=He suggested it could have been his son that produced the Self Portrait ( 1533 ) .
#Text=Some regard him as the last of the Flemish painters not to show an Italian influence . [ 2 ]
